South Orangetown Central School District voters passed the 2020-2021 school budget with 71% of the vote in the annual budget vote which culminated on June 16. The approved budget totals $96,839,306, reflects a 2.2% budget-to-budget increase and remains within the tax cap with a 2.82% tax levy increase. In all, 3,811 ballots were received for this year‚Äôs vote, compared with 1,598 in 2019 and 1,381 in 2018.

‚ÄúI am ever grateful for the continued support of our community, which is especially important during these challenging times,‚Äù said Superintendent of Schools Robert R. Pritchard, Ed.D. ‚ÄúThe benefit to our students is immeasurable and our community‚Äôs strong commitment to high-quality, public education for all students gives us all hope for a brighter future.‚Äù

Incumbents Leon Jacobs and Christine Lee were re-elected to the Board of Education. Their three-year terms begin July 1, 2020 and conclude June 30, 2023.

Detailed budget information is posted on the district Budget Vote webpage at https://blogs.socsd.org/2016socsd/budget-vote/

Congratulations to Tappan Zee High School Salutatorian Hannah Ahn, who was named a 2020 United States Presidential Scholar semifinalist, one of the highest national honors for high school students! Of the 5,600 students nationwide identified as candidates, just 621 were selected as semifinalists.

"To be recognized as a semifinalist in this prestigious and highly competitive program is such an honor for Hannah and for Tappan Zee High School,‚Äù TZHS Principal Rudy Arietta noted. ‚ÄúWhile we all know how special Hannah is, it‚Äôs awesome that her efforts have been recognized and that she is being honored as one of the most impressive young people across the nation."

The selection of the vast majority of candidates for the prestigious U.S. Department of Education program is based on SAT and ACT scores. Application is invitation-only; students may not apply and schools may not nominate candidates.

‚ÄúI was honored just to qualify for the program, so to finish as a semifinalist was such a great surprise!‚Äù said Ahn, who has committed to Harvard University. She plans to study Chemical Physics.

How to Support Your Child's Mental Health:
„ÉªLove: Be there for your child and show care and love
„ÉªSupport: Encourage and praise your child
„ÉªFeeling: Get to know how your child is feeling
„ÉªExercise: Exercise has physical and emotional benefits
„ÉªEducation: Learn signs and symptoms of mental health problems
„ÉªCoping: Help your child learn simple coping skills, such as relaxation
„ÉªConversation: Encourage your child to talk to you
„ÉªListen: Make sure to listen to what your child has to say
„ÉªBehavior: Keep an eye out for changes in behavior
„ÉªRest Time: Help your child build rest time into their routine

For more information, questions or concerns, email jinglis@socsd.org or jcursio@socsd.org.

2/4: Continuing with tips for supporting social emotional learning in the upper elementary grades...Cottage Lane Elementary School Psychologist Linda King suggests that keeping kids active, engaged and connected is key:

„ÉªEstablish and maintain routines, especially bedtime and mornings, to help provide children with a sense of stability and security.

„ÉªEat meals together when possible. Use this time to talk about what is happening in the family or outside of the family. Give kids other outlets for self-expression like dance, exercise, writing or drawing or crafts.

„ÉªStay connected with family and friends by establishing regular FaceTime, Zoom, Skype contact.

„ÉªGet outside! Exercise, even just a walk, should be part of daily routine.

„ÉªMake the most of family time by playing board games, reading, cooking or baking together.

„ÉªLet kids help out by doing chores and/or helping someone in need in the neighborhood or locally in a safe way that maintains social distance.

Tappan Zee High School Library Media Specialist Patty Eyer suggests boosting visual literacy skills as an engaging alternative to screen time. ‚ÄúVisual literacy is the ability to interpret, negotiate, and make meaning from information presented in the form of an image, extending the meaning of literacy, which commonly signifies interpretation of a written or printed text. Many social studies teachers rely on the use of primary sources to provide students with a contextual understanding of an event or time under study. So, break out those photo albums, love letters or print out images on any topic and use this tool from The Library of Congress to guide a family discussion: http://www.loc.gov/teachers/usingprimarysources/resources/Primary_Source_Analysis_Tool.pdf‚Äù

More ideas and links in Eyer‚Äôs blog post: https://blogs.socsd.org/tzlmc/2020/04/13/visual-literacy/

Of the 1.6 million juniors who entered the 2020 National Merit Scholarship Program by taking the 2018 Preliminary SAT/National Merit Scholarship Qualifying Test, the 15,000 who score highest in their state are named Semifinalists at the start of the senior year. To be considered for Finalist status, Semifinalists must submit an application demonstration leadership and outstanding academic performance and be recommended by a school official. Approximately 50 percent of Finalists are ultimately awarded a National Merit Scholarship.

Hannah was named a 2020 Semifinalist in the fall. Eight additional seniors earned Letters of Commendation for scoring in the top three percent of 2018 PSAT/NMSQT test takers.

Thirty-one Tappan Zee High School AP Biology students and science teachers Brian Newburger and Nicole Farish participated in a five-hour Human Mitochondrial Sequencing lab at the Regeneron DNA Learning Center affiliated with Cold Spring Harbor Laboratory. "This lab experience gave students with an interest in biotechnology a great leap forward," said Newburger.

Students utilized a Polymerase Chain Reaction (PCR) machine to amplify DNA and performed a gel electrophoresis to help analyze mitochondrial DNA to determine evolutionary relationships. Students will further analyze their DNA sequences using an online bioserver.

"It was fun and fulfilling to see our students so engaged in learning about and experiencing firsthand a few of the procedures involved in DNA technology," Farish noted. #SOCSDengages
